awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Improving Service Systems through Real-time and Delayed Information
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) award supports fundamental research intended to reduce congestion in critical services by enabling service providers to effectively disseminate information about delays to their customers.  This research will advance the national health and prosperity by enabling better access to healthcare and emergency resources and reducing congestion in urban mobility.  The availability of real time information through smartphone apps and display message technology has revolutionized the way many service systems interact with their customers.  This project will advance the understanding of how such information can be used to improve the availability and accessibility of these services.  The educational plan includes targeted outreach efforts to broaden participation of underrepresented groups in engineering research.

This project will study queueing networks in which delayed information on system state is offered to potential customers.  The research objective is to provide rigorous approximations of the performance of such systems.  The research will incorporate a multinomial logit model choice model to emulate customer arrival behavior in exponential and general queueing models.  Fluid limit and diffusion approximations will be used to model congested queues, where anticipated customer behavior will most heavily influence queueing dynamics.  Finite capacity queueing models will also be studied in the context of delayed information.  The approximations will be assessed via simulation as well as comparisons with observational data from real-world transportation systems and hospital emergency departments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Internet and mobile services often provide waiting time or queue length information to customers. This information allows a customer to determine whether to remain in line or, in the case of multiple lines, better decide which line to join. Unfortunately, there is usually a delay associated with waiting time information. Either the information itself is stale, or it takes time for the customers to travel to the service location after having received the information.  The major goal of this project is to understand how long a delay in information needs to be in order for a Hopf bifurcation to occur and cause unwanted oscillations in the underlying queueing system. For society to design, staff, and operate these queueing systems optimally, we must understand the fundamental stochastic behavior and mathematics that govern how the basic parameters of such a system will impact the performance of such a system.  

This project developed new mathematical tools to analyze queueing systems with delayed information.  The project was important because it not only showed how to approximate stochastic queueing models with delay differential equations, but it also showed how to analyze the delay differential equations themselves. There were three main gaps in the research literature that were closed due to this project.  First, we showed rigorously that scaled stohastic queueing models converged to delay differential equations or functional differential equations in the fluid limit.  The second part was to analyze when these delay differential equations would have a Hopf bifurcation (oscillations) depending on the model parameters.  The last part was to analyze the size of the oscillations.  In some settings, approximations were obtained, however, in the case where the delay is in the form of an update, the size of the oscillations can be obtained exactly.  

The knowledge obtained was disseminated to other researchers at top conferences and journal publications, and has already had a significant impact on the academic study of such models.  In addition, the findings were incorporated into classes at both the undergraduate and Ph.D. level in Cornell University ORIE program, ensuring that the next generation of leaders in operations research can benefit from our new understanding the impact of delayed information in queueing models and stochastic networks.  The research also formed the core of two Ph.D. student's doctoral thesis.  Both graduate students have successfully defended their theses and have moved on to apply this knowledge in industry settings.  The research also showed that it could have impact in practical settings such as smartphone apps that provide waiting times to customers, which is the standard in hospitals, amusement parks, and other entertainment venues.  

 


Last Modified: 01/04/2024
Modified by: Jamol Pender
